column1: #TellUsTigers x #Thanksgiving: “Gratitude is hardly a big enough word to describe what I feel for Tony Whalen::: my close friend::: bandmate and collaborator for 27 years — until his death from COVID-19 on March 25::: 2020. If you knew him::: he was all about bigger and better. I can trace so many positive things in my life to Tony. Tony and I started three bands::: all with me on guitar and him on drums. Playing music and shows with him was some of the most fun I’ll ever have::: and I am eternally grateful for that. In the days and weeks after Tony died::: everyone I work with at Princeton Entrepreneurship Council (PEC)::: the Office of the Dean for Research and around campus lifted me up. I’m lucky to call these people friends and colleagues. PEC and Princeton Innovation put on a lot of virtual events in 2020::: and we were doing more working from home than even I thought possible. I’m grateful that the work I do at #PrincetonU contributes to making society better. Staying busy doing this important work has helped me to keep going during the pandemic and to process my own grief at losing Tony. He and I met the first week of college::: at @Rider_University in 1993. Tony was one of those people that you hope to have in your college life — he made everything more colorful and memorable. He was creative::: charismatic::: inspirational and hilariously inappropriate at times. Tony made Rider and our community there better. And he wanted the best for you::: even if you only knew him for five minutes. He was one of the first people who opened the door into my career in design. He commissioned me for a logo design in 1997 and from there::: we embarked on one creative project after another together. When Tony died::: I plunged into several creative projects to honor him. The biggest one was to produce ‘Tony Whalen: Legend and Legacy:::’ an hour-long documentary about the impact he had on Rider::: his friends and his family. It was an honor for me to keep his spirit and memory alive. Although he’s gone::: Tony can still be with us if I can make things around me better too.” — Wright Seneres::: social media/marketing specialist::: Princeton Entrepreneurship Council; photo by Alexander Moravcsik ’23 #Princetagram
column3: This is very grrat. Thanks Wright . Happy Thanksgiving!
column4: Betty Whalen

In regions of Africa wracked by poaching::: people have observed an increased incidence of elephants without their tusks::: which are prized in the wildlife black market. But there has been no direct genetic evidence indicating how this was happening::: or why this trait was occurring exclusively in female elephants — until now.

High Meadows Environmental Institute researchers have now implicated two genes associated with tooth development in mammals to be at the center of the tuskless elephant phenomenon.

PRINCETON.EDU
Princeton scientists identify genes behind tusklessness in African elephants facing poaching pressure

To be a Princetonian is to Vote!

Students::: faculty and staff stopped by to show off their support for democracy with Princeton Vote100 and Princeton University Office of the Dean of Undergraduate Students.

In the 2020 election::: New Jersey had the highest youth vote in the country. At Princeton::: the Vote100 initiative helped significantly increase student registration and voting rates last year. Nearly 88% of voting-eligible Princeton students registered and 75% voted on Election Day 2020::: compared with 50% of eligible students who voted in 2016.

Learn more about Vote 100 and how #PrincetonU students are getting out the vote both here in New Jersey and across the country: https://bit.ly/3GKP56N

#ElectionDay

column1: #TellUsTigers: “As we sat in after-school traffic in Morelia::: México::: my mom used to play CDs of popular Latin American folk music. She shared her favorite boleros and explained how certain art songs became national treasures in their home country. She’d tell me: ‘You should sing these pieces someday.’ I grew up with a deep love for Latin American music and its power to move audiences across México. Whether performed in concert halls or a tiny living room packed with family::: I felt incredibly proud of this rich musical tradition that I shared with my parents and abuelitos. As I grew up studying classical music::: I felt that Latin American folk and popular music was not given enough of a platform. Today::: as a conductor and vocalist::: I’m dedicated to sharing songs and soundscapes from the Latin American canon with orchestral and choral ensembles. While I was a student at #PrincetonU::: I conducted @princetoncamerata in a concert of classical Mexican repertoire; it brought me immense joy to share music I loved since I was a kid with my peers and the community. I also conducted a beloved bolero with the Princeton Glee Club in Mexico City in Feb. 2020. These heartwarming experiences intensified my drive to create spaces for this repertoire to be performed by folks who grew up with these songs::: the way I did::: as well as singers who’d never heard of them before. This fall::: my dream of starting a new choir::: Alegría::: has become a reality with support from Glee Club director Gabriel Crouch and the Glee Club community. Its mission is to perform works by Latinx composers and Latin American folk music arranged for full choir. The piece we’re rehearsing in this video::: ‘Fina Estampa:::’ is an Afro-Peruvian waltz written by Chabuca Granda. It tells the story of an animated sidewalk that awakens from the splendor of a beautiful person strolling by.” — Mariana Corichi Gómez ’21::: choral & Trenton Arts at Princeton associate. Video by Kirsten Pardo ’24. Hear Alegría’s debut performance 7:30 p.m. Oct. 29 in Richardson Auditorium (and livestream) at the Glee Club’s free “Hand in Hand” concert with Harvard & Yale to benefit Save The Music::: a nonprofit focused on equity in music education.

column1: Over the course of the last week::: #Princeton2025 students bonded through Small Group Experiences::: an Orientation program that helps ease the transition to college while allowing them to engage with the world around them.  Community Action (CA) is coordinated by Pace Center for Civic Engagement::: Princeton University and introduces first-year students to service projects throughout our local communities.  Dialogue and Difference in Action (DDA) provides first-years with the opportunity to engage in critical conversations around identity::: power::: privilege and difference both in the context of the #PrincetonU community and society at-large.  Outdoor Action (OA) lets students disconnect from distractions and get to know nature through activities like canoeing::: biking and hiking at local parks.

column1: Meet Coach::: the newest member of Princeton University Department of Public Safety! 🐶  Coach is a service dog for first responders::: and her job is to provide comfort and affection to the #PrincetonU community and DPS employees. The 17-month-old black lab retriever is a recent graduate of Puppies Behind Bars::: an organization that trains prison inmates to raise service dogs. She has over 10:::000 hours of socialization with volunteers! 🧡🖤  Detective Sergeant Al Flanders has helped Coach get acclimated to campus and has taught her tricks::: from giving high fives to posing for photos. She even has her own TigerCard. 📸  Be sure to follow @CoachAtPrinceton on Instagram and::: of course::: don't hesitate to come up to her for lots of pets and snuggles when you see her around campus. #NationalDogDay

column1: Effective today::: August 11::: all faculty::: staff and students regardless of vaccination status::: must wear a face covering indoors in buildings occupied by the University. Exceptions to this requirement include when in one’s own dormitory room or suite::: when working alone in a room or cubicle or when actively eating or drinking.  This indoor face covering requirement will be evaluated weekly by a team of physicians and scientists. The next update on the indoor face covering requirement will be communicated to the campus community by August 23.  Visit the Princeton COVID-19 Policies and Guidance page for more information: https://bit.ly/3CI0l1N
column3: Please note: By August 23::: the University will update guidance regarding teaching and classroom use. Further::: we will communicate the next update on the indoor face covering requirement::: as the policy will be evaluated weekly by a team of physicians and scientists. By September 15::: the University will determine whether to end::: modify or extend the indoor face coverings requirement. This time will allow us to evaluate the COVID case rate of the campus community following the increase in students::: faculty and staff returning for the fall semester.

#TellUsTigers: “As a woman of color who designs and sews historical costumes::: I don’t often see people like myself represented. I try to be mindful about who I ask to model my costumes::: so that I can increase the diversity of BIPOC images in the community. I’m excited about the Afrofuturist idea of taking parts of different histories::: stories and symbols and rewriting them through costuming to create a new narrative or work of art. I designed the costume I’m wearing here based on the character Winter Hayle-Blackburn from my favorite book series in middle school::: ‘The Lunar Chronicles’ by Marissa Meyer::: YA Author. Winter is the princess of Luna and proudly wears three scars down the side of her face as proof of her refusal to succumb to the wishes of her cruel stepmother Queen Levana. Most of the YA books I read back then had white protagonists::: so to find a character who I admired so much::: who was also not only Black but had a mixed racial identity::: meant the world to me! My design draws inspiration from Greek chitons — a tunic that fastens at the shoulder — and the drape of sari garments to highlight the cultural influences of both Winter’s home of Luna and her late mother. I’ve been sewing since I was 6 years old::: but I got into historical costuming in high school. I lean towards historical fantasy/historically inspired work rather than historical reproduction because it gives me freedom to counter the lack of mainstream BIPOC images in these eras. For example::: I might photograph myself in a buttoned-up 1910s European gown with my natural hair out and unstyled::: the focus being the natural contrast between these images or symbols. As a co-leader of Trenton Youth Theater (Trenton Arts at Princeton) at #PrincetonU last year::: I taught a couple of costume design workshops. I drew on the show ‘Natasha Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812:::’ one of my favorite examples of historical costume in theater. Hearing the students dissect & offer their opinions on a work I had admired for so long was exciting. I can't wait to be back on campus with other artists to collaborate and make art together!” — Tanaka Ngwara ’24; 📷 by Ella Claire Morgan ’24 #Princetagram
column3: Ms. Ngwara is amazing and I look forward to following her career.

#TellUsTigers x #Princetalove: “Last summer::: I photographed my Princeton classmates La Lee Lo and My (pronounced ‘me’) Bui::: the beautiful couple in these photos::: for their wedding::: a multi-ceremony celebration of Vietnamese::: Hmong and Catholic cultures. Their celebration also reflected their story of meeting as first-generation::: lower-income students at Princeton who are now building a life together back in their hometown of St. Paul::: Minnesota. I wrote about them for Portrait of a Young Couple::: a photojournalism project I founded to photograph couples’ weddings for free in exchange for hosting me in their home and permission to tell their story to the wider world. (You can see me standing with La Lee and My in the photo in front of My’s mother’s home.) When I graduated from #PrincetonU::: photography was still just a hobby of mine. I studied electrical engineering and felt obligated to spend some time after graduation working in the field. But something was missing::: and I soon realized how my hobby in photography gave me something my job in engineering never could: a reason to spend time with anyone I met in life. At Princeton::: everyone needed a nice photo of themselves at some point; dancers::: actors::: musicians::: academics; on stages::: in labs::: standing proudly in front of Nassau Hall with their senior theses. With my camera::: I had reason to spend time with all these incredible people. That idea stayed with me::: along with a question: if my camera afforded so many relationships at Princeton::: how many more could it afford across the world? My answer was Portrait of a Young Couple. Weddings are one of the few celebrations common across all peoples::: no matter their ethnicity::: religion::: political views::: career or socioeconomic status. Photography is one of the most important and intimate jobs at a wedding::: and so it naturally presents a rare and authentic opportunity to document a couple’s story. I’ve photographed 30 weddings for the project so far::: and I hope to begin traveling internationally next year to document the stories of countless more people.” — Vincent Po '18

column1: Co-authored by Princeton School of Public and International Affairs professor Noreen Goldman::: an updated analysis of American COVID-19 deaths throughout 2020 reveals a reduced overall life expectancy by 1.31 years — the largest single-year decline in life expectancy in at least 40 years. column1: Alan Turing *38 was born on this day in 1912.  During his life::: Turing achieved groundbreaking discoveries in the world of computer sciences and was central to breaking the Enigma codes in WWII. He is credited with shortening the war and saving thousands of lives. After enduring forced estrogen injections because he was openly gay::: he died in 1954 at the age of 41.  A portrait of Turing was unveiled at #PrincetonU in 2019::: serving “as a visible expression of Princeton as the welcoming community we are today::: even as we continue to strive to become ever more inclusive and diverse in the years ahead." ➡️ https://bit.ly/2Z5A9Lw  Today::: the Bank of England's new £50 note::: featuring a portrait of Turing::: entered circulation. ➡️ https://bbc.in/3gVF4rz #Pride

column1: On June 19::: 1865::: Major General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston::: Texas and read a federal order declaring that "all slaves are free." This order came two years after President Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation.  To recognize the significance of #Juneteenth::: the University will officially observe the holiday::: in celebration of the significance of the day and contemplate how we can do our part to eliminate structural and overt racism and other forms of discrimination on our campus::: in our communities::: and in our country. The observance of the Juneteenth holiday is one of many initiatives underway at Princeton to support racial equity.  This year::: #PrincetonU offered employees a copy of Annette Gordon-Reed's book “On Juneteenth.” Gordon provides a historian's view of the country's long road to Juneteenth::: recounting both its origins in Texas and the hardships that African-Americans have faced since.  President Eisgruber reflects on the book as well as the University’s decision to observe Juneteenth as holiday in his latest blog post: https://bit.ly/35CvKDr

#TellUsTigers: “What only my closest friends can guess from the constant murmur of humming::: whistling and soft singing they hear when around me is that I always have music playing in my head. The ‘Allegro assai’ from Bach’s Sonata no. 3 for solo violin that I’m playing in this video is frequently the background music for my life::: every note following in perfect perpetual motion even as every day does anything but. As coach of the first violin section of the Trenton Youth Orchestra::: directed by the incredible Lou Chen ’19::: my favorite thing to do was to have everyone sing their part. You can practice violin every waking hour::: and you will never progress as much as you would from singing for just five minutes. One of the things I’m most grateful for at Princeton is learning from so many amazing musicians — from rehearsals with my friends in Princeton University Orchestra and Princeton Camerata to special moments such as playing in chamber groups::: touring with the orchestra across Spain and performing Mendelssohn’s ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ under the baton of the legendary Gustavo Dudamel during his #PrincetonU residency. These musical role models sculpted the way I think::: sing and breathe. It felt like a true coming-of-age moment when I started noticing myself quoting my teachers and mentors while I coached TYO sectionals. During the pandemic::: I spent a lot of time reflecting on my life at Princeton: I realized the most formative things I’ve done could only have happened here. I never seriously thought about studying violin at a conservatory::: but I suspect that even if I had::: my relationship with music wouldn’t be half as meaningful as it is today. Every day brought endless serendipity::: musical or otherwise::: and I was always happiest when I stumbled upon the newest thing Princeton had to offer. My advice to incoming first-years::: which I’ve heard from the people I admire as I prepare to move to Silicon Valley to start work as a software engineer::: is cultivate the unexpected::: remain vexingly curious and enjoy the background music of your life as you do amazing things.” — Nick Schmeller ’21; video by David Kelly Crow

#TellUsTigersPartII: "I submitted my medical school applications soon after my 2020 ‘couch graduation’ from Princeton::: courtesy of the pandemic. The next weekend::: I moved to New York to pursue my dream of starting the first luxury fashion brand for women of color. I’ve always known I was destined to pursue multiple passions. Shadowing a C-section in a small Louisiana Army hospital at age 13::: where my mother was a nurse::: inspired my medical journey. Starting Tiger Trends::: the first fashion editorial at #PrincetonU as a sophomore (when I was first featured in #TellUsTigers) ignited my love of fashion. While fashion and medicine seemingly have little in common::: both must improve one element: equity. As a Black female anesthesiologist::: I plan to address important discrepancies in healthcare for people of color that result in disproportionately high mortality rates for new mothers::: a struggle to find effective mental health resources and more. As a Black female designer::: I will use my fashion brand pAx to celebrate the versatility of women within the WOC community::: showcasing beauty that lies outside the Eurocentric standard::: an unrealistic standard that has dominated the fashion industry too long. We source our materials from Black and brown-owned businesses — including the white fabric of the skirt I designed and am wearing here with a bodice top from Vaquera; and the cotton in our classic tee::: in the second photo. We work exclusively with POC creatives — this includes photographers::: hairstylists::: seamstresses and more. Our executive team is entirely comprised of women of color. Over time::: I’ll develop pAx into the next luxury conglomerate like LVMH::: but one that acquires and supports other designers and brands that amplify POC talent. Last week::: pAx finished our SS22 collection. This weekend::: I’m moving to DC to attend Howard University College of Medicine. I don’t anticipate that accomplishing both my goals will be easy but the best things usually aren’t. I often joke that I feel like a double agent::: but I wouldn’t have it any other way.” — Sara Howell ’20; 📷 by David Kelly Crow #Princetagram

column1: #TellUsTigers x #WellnessWednesday: "On June 1::: I got my second vaccine shot. It was a bittersweet day for me — I lost my oldest son Josh in August 2012 from a heroin overdose and June 1 is his birthday. He would have been 35. But I felt more comfortable with the vaccine::: knowing my son would protect me. At the onset of the pandemic::: I really wasn’t worried. After all it was only supposed to be for two weeks. As time went on::: I started to worry about my mom::: who is 73 and has health issues. #COVID19 could really affect her. I have been unable to give her a hug or kiss this whole time. Luckily::: neither she nor my stepfather got the virus. They isolated themselves from everyone. Canceled Easter dinner in 2020. I would talk with my mom on the phone regularly. She would let me see her from time to time::: as long as I wore a mask & kept my distance. She only allowed this because I was part of the University’s weekly testing program. She canceled Thanksgiving. My two sons::: who are 33 and 28::: were very upset::: so I made Thanksgiving for us. At Christmas we went to my mom’s::: but sadly only for about an hour to exchange gifts. There was no food or drink::: we had to wear masks and socially distance. Still no hugs or kisses. When the vaccine first became available::: I was wary like many people. My mom::: stepfather::: sister and brother-in-law all received the Moderna vaccine and had minimal side effects. My mom asked me a million times to get vaccinated. Then a good friend who also works at Princeton told me the Pfizer vaccine was available at the University and asked if I would go with them. I called my doctor to see if it was ok. I had a minor case of COVID in March 2021. On May 11::: my doctor gave me the green light::: and my friend and I received our first shot later that day. On June 15::: it will be two weeks after my second shot::: and I’m going to my mom’s to give her the biggest hug and kiss. I can’t wait! I feel good that I am protecting my family and my co-workers. I hope others will feel assured that the vaccine is completely safe." — Jeff Coley::: worker in the roof/tin shop::: Facilities Operations::: and president of the Service Employees International Union 175

column1: The accomplishments of Princeton’s advanced-degree recipients will be celebrated at the #Princeton21 virtual Hooding ceremony.

#TellUsTigers: “My father never finished high school::: nor his father before him::: but both he and my mother sacrificed to ensure that cycle would be broken. I was always taught to cherish my education. From an early age::: I understood that education is a right that was not always granted to people like me. My father::: Greg::: unfortunately::: passed away this August due to complications of COVID-19. One of the last conversations I had with him was telling him that I had been accepted into Harvard Law School. That was three days before he was admitted into the hospital. He sounded quieter that day but I didn’t understand why until much later. He had always told my mother::: ‘I want to see him get his first degree.’ My dad realized that education::: formal or otherwise::: is something you must take and keep a hold of because it’s what gives you power in this world. Most importantly::: my father taught me that on my quest to achieve excellence::: I should care for people along my path and strive to leave the world better than the one I was born into. To that end::: I think my professional decision to attend law school is the biggest one I’ve made so far. [Social justice] played a huge role. In my law school personal statement::: I tied together references from ‘Changes’ by Tupac and excerpts from Ta-Nehisi Coates’ book::: “Between the World and Me:::" because they remind me that although it’s so easy to get pessimistic about the world::: we shouldn’t sulk or give up. As a lawyer::: I want to be someone who helps reform and improve some of our oldest institutions and systems. If society is like a big machine::: then lawyers are the people who read the blueprints to that machine as they decipher and help change laws to ensure things run smoothly. Those who came before me fought and sacrificed to leave me a better world. In keeping with the lessons from my parents::: and in using everything I have learned in my four years at #PrincetonU::: I hope to do the same by continually serving others.” — G. Terrell Seabrooks ’21::: Spirit of Princeton award winner. This narrative is adapted from a U.S. Lacrosse magazine profile. Lead 📷 by Alexander Moravcsik ’23 #Princetagram #Princeton21 #FLi

column1: In a letter to the Princeton University community::: President Eisgruber shares plans to have a fully residential fall semester::: in-person teaching and learning and a normal academic calendar. We are requiring all students to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19::: and to provide proof of vaccination by August 1::: 2021::: in order to enroll for the fall semester. The University is considering ways to increase vaccination rates across campus::: including a potential vaccination requirement for faculty and staff. For now::: we are asking everyone who works at Princeton to get vaccinated as soon as possible and to upload their vaccination status to VacStatus. column4: An open letter to Trevor Noah:  MAY 14::: 2021::: 12:24 AM  I just watched your 10-minute monologue on the Israeli-Hamas conflict for your popular television program “The Daily Show” (May 11).  Frankly::: it wasn’t easy viewing. In fact::: I began talking back to the screen::: but::: obviously::: to no avail::: so I chose instead to write you this open letter.  You framed your comments quite cleverly by suggesting there were competing narratives out there::: depending on who was doing the talking and the starting point of their version of history.  And then::: as if nothing more than a curious third party::: you waded into the debate::: essentially assigning yourself a certain moral credibility because of your “non-combatant“ status.  But we are not entirely in a post-truth society yet::: at least I hope not::: where facts no longer exist and opinions rule the day::: especially when catapulted into the public square by celebrity status and legions of admiring followers.  So::: for example::: when you assert that the British took the land from the Palestinians::: not quite.  Actually::: the British took the land from the Ottoman Turks::: who had ruled there for centuries. Palestinians never had a sovereign state of their own. The Jews did::: by the way::: though that was vanquished by the Romans nearly 2:::000 years ago.  But to fast forward::: this conflict::: at its heart::: is about two competing national movements::: and the only logical way to resolve it is by a negotiated settlement — two states for two peoples.  Simpler said than done::: of course::: and here we come to demonstrable facts::: not simply personal opinions.  The UN recommended precisely such a two-state settlement as early as 1947. It was accepted by the Jews::: rejected by the Arabs.  From 1948 to 1967::: the West Bank::: eastern Jerusalem::: and Gaza were all in Arab::: not Jewish::: hands. A Palestinian state could have been created at any time. It wasn’t.  During 2000-1::: Israel::: joined by President Bill Clinton::: offered a viable two-state accord to the Palestinians (incidentally::: one of several offers in the past 20 years). They refused. That’s not my conclusion::: but Clinton’s::: as described in his autobiography::: “My Life.”  Then we come to 2005::: which has direct relevance to your monologue. Israel unilaterally withdrew its forces and settlers from Gaza::: giving local residents their first chance in history to govern themselves::: something Ottoman Turkey and Egypt had never done. By 2007::: the Palestinian Authority was violently ousted and Hamas took control. It has wielded power ruthlessly ever since.  What exactly is Hamas::: a point you skipped in your take on the Middle East?  It is a terrorist organization. That’s not a personal view. It is the formal designation of the United States and the 27-member European Union.  What’s the goal of Hamas::: again missing from your comments? Israel’s annihilation and replacement by an Islamist regime. Those are frequently expressed and well-documented sentiments of Hamas leaders.  So you skip these relevant facts — the violent nature of Hamas::: its doctrinal aims::: or::: for that matter::: its split with the Palestinian Authority — and zero in on the current round of conflict::: looking at it::: above all::: from the perspective of power ratios.  You bemoan the imbalance::: asserting it’s not a “fair fight” because Israel is the stronger party.  You compare casualties::: simplistically suggesting the side with the higher number is somehow automatically granted victim status.  You even try to offer a rationale for the Hamas actions by referring to threatened evictions of four Palestinian families in Jerusalem::: failing to note that this is a longstanding legal issue in the Israeli court system.  You suggest that Israel triggered Hamas’s ire by harassing Muslims during Ramadan::: which is a total misrepresentati on of the facts::: not to mention that Israel has repeatedly gone to great lengths to protect the right of worship for all faiths — something quite rare in that part of the world.  Let’s be clear: Hamas’s ire for Israel is permanent::: as is its goal of one day dominating Palestinian allegiances not only in Gaza::: but in eastern Jerusalem and the West Bank::: as part of its larger strategy.  And you even try to compare the situation to your own childhood::: recalling that your mother told you not to hit your younger siblings::: even when provoked::: because you were bigger and stronger.  Sorry::: but your younger siblings were not plotting murder and wreaking societal havoc. You’re ignoring the true nature of Hamas::: the fact that it’s been firing 1000s of missiles over the years::: building cross-border terror tunnels::: kidnapping Israelis::: and foregoing development in Gaza to focus on damaging Israel.  You’re downplaying the trauma of millions of Israelis rushing to bomb shelters::: caring for the elderly and disabled::: and comforting traumatized children::: as rockets fly overhead today and could strike anywhere::: even with the Iron Dome anti-missile system in place.  You’re laudably concerned about children::: but are neglecting the instrumentaliza tion of Palestinian kids at the hands of a cynical Hamas regime that knows images of young victims will change the entire story for those who only see the photos::: not the context.  And you sidestep a key question — what is Israel supposed to do under such circumstances::: when your mother’s advice to you seems totally detached from the sober reality it faces? What would any country do::: when the traditional tools of diplomacy — from conflict management to conflict resolution — don’t stand a chance with an ideologically and theologically driven Hamas?  Finally::: allow me to stress one point. I don’t view this conflict simply as an endless debate to prove one side right and the other side wrong. Not at all. Rather::: my decades-long involvement in the region::: my many trips to Israel and the Arab world::: including Palestinian territories::: has one central dream — peace::: enduring peace.  I believe that to be the quest of the vast majority of Israelis::: among them my and my wife’s close family members. They have not experienced a single day of true peace since 1948::: nor their families who were survivors of the Holocaust::: refugees from communism::: or victims of evictions from Arab countries.  Israel was not reborn to be in permanent conflict. The fact that six Arab countries now have normalized ties with Israel is a powerful reminder that peace is attainable::: and that Israel is keenly on the lookout for partners.  One day::: that peace will be realized::: I pray::: with the Palestinians. But it won’t happen as long as Hamas rules Gaza::: clings to its genocidal goals::: and snookers well-meaning people abroad to believe it’s the victim in a conflict::: alas::: of its own making.  ABOUT THE AUTHOR: David Harris is the CEO of the American Jewish Committee (AJC).

column1: Tonight::: we are a shining a light on you::: #PrincetonU. As the academic year comes to a close and with #Princeton21 Commencement upon us::: we are grateful for each and every Princetonian for all that you have done to address the challenges of a historically difficult chapter in the history of our University and our world. To the teams in our Office of Information Technology::: the McGraw Center::: and Instructional Support Services who enabled us to move Princeton online and create hybrid learning opportunities; to the staff in Campus Dining::: Facilities::: Campus Life and other departments who continue coming to campus to support our students and operations; to all the people who enabled us to restart laboratories and reopen libraries; to the undergraduates::: graduate students and faculty who embraced innovation and creativity to teach and learn effectively in an online environment::: and to the staff who supported those efforts; to the colleagues in University Health Services::: Environmental Health and Safety::: the Department of Public Safety::: and other units who worked diligently to keep us all safe and healthy; to all the people who creatively juggled family and workplace responsibilities; to our alumni who found new ways to connect with one another and with our students; to the staff who took on new responsibilities or worked tirelessly to keep their departments running as smoothly as possible; to students::: faculty::: and staff who found ways to reach out and assist the communities around them; and to everyone who stepped up to ensure the health and safety of our community. We have emerged stronger::: more resilient and more vibrant because of you.

column5: Racism is happening right before your eyes...what will Princeton do about it? Recent reports in the Inquirer and BillyPenn have revealed the presence of human remains of the Africa family child victims of the MOVE bombing in the collections of the University of Pennsylvania Museum and Princeton University. Why have these remains not been returned to the family? There is no possible justification for this cruel and disrespectful treatment of Black Philadelphians.   Further::: these human remains have even been used as teaching props in a public enrollment course hosted by Princeton University and taught by Janet Monge. Use of the remains of people’s family members is shameful.  As a member of the Princeton community::: I call on all of you to use your influence to advocate for the Africa family’s demands::: which are:  The immediate RETURN of the remains of victims of the MOVE bombing to the Africa family.  An immediate APOLOGY by the University of Pennsylvania and the Penn Museum to the Africa family and the Black community of Philadelphia for the Museum’s racist and abhorrent behavior.  Financial REPARATIONS to the Africa family for the continued harm and trauma caused by the University and the Penn Museum’s use of their relatives as teaching tools::: and by Coursera for their profits made from the abuse of these remains.  The immediate REMOVAL of all online content in which these remains are used::: including the online course Real Bones taught by Janet Monge.  The TERMINATION of Janet Monge from her role as curator at the Penn Museum and faculty in the department of anthropology.  In addition::: I call for the creation of a transparent::: public investigation led by a community-elect ed investigator and funded by the University::: into how these specific remains ended up being used by the university and it's role in perpetuating racism.

#TellUsTigers: "My first book::: ‘Every Day the River Changes:::’ will soon be published by Catapult::: and I can’t help but think about how it all began — as my #SeniorThesis. My project was different than most: Princeton::: being the magical place it is::: had agreed to send me to Colombia::: where I would travel the entire thousand-mile length of the country’s legendary Río Magdalena and write about the people I met living by its banks. That’s how I got to know folks like Don Pira::: the older man pictured beside me. He lived alone on a patch of riverside land and supported himself by fishing and picking plantains day after day in the sweltering heat. I’ll never forget our journey to reach him::: an hour’s canoe ride through wetlands and flat pastures. The rising sun gave light to river turtles slipping off logs and red howler monkeys stirring in the guadua trees. The only wild and invasive hippopotamuses living outside Africa wallowed in our midst. Don Pira told me one of them had chased him off his land recently. Encounters like these filled the pages of my notebook::: and soon I realized I had a much bigger story on my hands. Colombia is one of the most complex and fascinating places I’ve ever reported from::: ‘Every Day the River Changes’ is a portrait of the nation as it recovers from more than half a century of conflict::: told through a tale of lively adventure along a majestic river now at risk. By featuring local voices::: I hope this book will foster a more nuanced understanding of an often-misunderstood country. Since graduating from #PrincetonU in 2019::: I’ve been freelancing as a journalist::: writing about people and nature for @natgeo::: @nytimes and more. That’s what I think travel writing can do in today's world: encourage empathy across cultures near and far. With my first book on the way::: I’m just getting started::: but I can’t help but hope to be a voice leading that charge for my generation someday. Wandering the world in search of stories is a dream come true for me. I invite you to follow me for more stories from across the globe. I can’t wait to have you along for the ride." — Jordan Salama '19 #Princetagram #TellUsTigersPartII #EveryDayTheRiverChanges

This week::: Governor Murphy announced that on April 19 all individuals ages 16 and older will be eligible for vaccination. We encourage everyone to register with the state and take any opportunity to get vaccinated: https://bit.ly/3sVssFr  DSL approval and submission of a Risk Assessment form are no longer required for eligible students that have a vaccine appointment in New Jersey and will return to campus the same day. These students only need to register their travel: https://bit.ly/3rYLJEA  Eligible students with a vaccine appointment that will require them to leave New Jersey and/or be away from campus for more than 24 hours must receive DSL approval before registering their travel at https://bit.ly/3rYLJEA  Students leaving New Jersey or who will be away from campus for more than 24 hours must also complete a Risk Assessment form before returning to campus and may be required to quarantine: https://bit.ly/3dGLJUH  Princeton can provide support for students traveling locally to receive the vaccine through the University Safety-Net Fund. Those looking for this support must fill out a request form: https://bit.ly/3mqcT6p  Students are encouraged to plan their first and::: if applicable::: second vaccine appointments based on the academic calendar and their scheduled move-out date. The University will not provide housing for students who have appointments scheduled beyond their move-out date.  Students who have appointments that conflict with an academic commitment should consult with their Director of Studies.

column1: Please join us for the fourth Gillett G. Griffin Memorial lecture with guest Raina Lampkins-Fielder::: curator of The Souls Grown Deep Foundation::: an organization dedicated to improving the quality of life of communities that gave rise to the art made by African American artists of the South::: including such artists as the Gee's Bend quiltmakers.  Collaborating with master printers::: several of the quilting artists::: supported by the foundation::: have made etchings with Paulson Press in Berkeley::: California. Using innovative techniques to transfer the quilt design to an etching plate::: a printable image now allows more people to own and enjoy the work of these artists.  In 2017::: three spectacular new etchings of Gee's Bend quilts were acquired for Firestone Library’s African American Studies Room (B floor) thanks to a joint initiative between the Princeton University Art Museum::: Princeton University Library::: and the Department of African American Studies. The prints include the quilt art of Mary Lee Bendolph and Loretta Pettway.

column1: #TellUsTigers x #Princetalove x #ValentineDay: “The first time I met Wendy::: we had just sat down next to each other in the first class of our Freshman Seminar::: ‘Can Virtue Be Taught? An Introduction to the Liberal Arts:::’ which was also our first Princeton class ever. As an icebreaker::: the professor asked us each to talk about the things we were passionate about. Wendy went first and spoke about her love for music and tennis; this made me somewhat uncomfortable::: because I had to go second::: and the only things I had in mind were music and tennis. The first words I ever spoke in a #PrincetonU classroom will forever be repeating exactly what the pretty girl next to me had just said — although Wendy swears that she never thought anything of it. That would turn out to be the only class we’d ever take together. (Wendy got a significantly better grade than I did. I’m totally over it::: though. Honestly. I rarely think about it::: and it almost never comes up in casual conversation). We hit it off immediately that day::: bonding over our mutual interests (which I was perhaps too eager to prove were genuine) on our long hike back to the Forbes addition::: where we both happened to live. For over a year we remained just friends::: until I finally came to my senses and asked her out on our first date: lunch plans at Teresa’s::: which turned into 3pm Panera Bread when we both overslept. A month later::: on Dec. 6::: 2012::: Wendy asked me to ask her to be my girlfriend. (I had no idea I was supposed to ask. I swear I’m not as clueless in other parts of my life.) And exactly eight years after that::: through years of long distance and slow dances in dorm rooms and presidencies of rival Asian culture clubs and anniversary Panera dates and extremely rainy graduation ceremonies and new careers and a wedding postponement due to the global #COVID19 pandemic::: we came back to where it all started::: getting married on Dec. 6::: 2020::: by our close friend::: classmate::: and officiant Vivian Qin on the steps of Blair Arch — the same steps we once walked on our way back to Forbes::: talking about music and tennis.” — Brandon Shih '15::: with Wendy Gu '15; wedding photo by Sophie Kaye Photography

#TellUsTigers: “There was never a dull moment growing up in the Black funeral home my mother owned in Newark::: New Jersey. After school::: my brother and I played hide-and-seek between and inside caskets. Our chores included rolling old Star-Ledger newspapers used to prop up bodies for wakes. In the summers::: when I wasn’t at basketball camp::: I passed out peppermints and tissues to family members of the deceased. I knew I didn’t want to make a living burying the dead. But I was spellbound by the way we mourn. I witnessed the electricity and elegance of Black grief. The adorned body laid out in an open casket. Elders dressed in their Sunday best telling stories of the good ol’ days. Teenagers with a classmate’s face emblazoned on R.I.P. T-shirts. A spirited eulogy followed by a festive repast where soul food is served and family drama unfolds. A ritual of death transformed into a celebration of life. It was the germ that grew into my scholarly work. My interest in African American mourning and social justice movements began in August 2014. Two months after graduating from Princeton Seminary::: I travelled to Ferguson::: Missouri to protest the shooting death of Michael Brown at the hands of white police officer Darren Wilson. I was fascinated by how Brown’s memorial was an epicenter of protest activity. At Princeton::: I was eager to make sense of my experiences in Ferguson and my family’s funeral parlor. Ironically::: as I began studying African American mourning::: I experienced a spell of personal loss. Within eight months::: my family buried my father and brother. It was the hardest year of my life. I was debilitated by grief. But thanks to the support of my loved ones and my advisers::: professors Eddie Glaude and Imani Perry::: I am completing my dissertation. The spirit of my brother and father::: and the deep abiding love of my mother::: continue to guide me along this exciting journey. More than anything::: I want to make them proud and carry on the legacy that made me and my work possible.” — Nyle Fort::: graduate student in religion and interdisciplinary humanities with a concentration in African American studies #Princetagram
column3: What is personal is your power::: hold on to it::: drive it and let it also take you to unexpected places. You are a change maker by this very post. Congratulations on your courageous transformation of grief into such celebration.
column4: Thank you for sharing your story. Glad you choose Princeton to continue your studies and hope someday you can publish your work so I can read it
column5: Riveting depiction of family::: love::: death::: grief::: support::: legacy and determination.🥰
column6: Wow::: I want to hear more from you.
column8: Thanks so much for sharing your story::: Nyle - Praying so hard for you and your family::: and know that God is::: and will continue to use you in amazing ways!

column1: In view of ongoing concerns related to the pandemic::: Reunions and the postponed Commencement ceremony for the Class of 2020 will not take place on campus this spring. The University has determined that inviting alumni back to campus from around the world is not prudent or possible. Reunions will be held as a virtual event this May. The University is working with the Class of 2020 to find ways to honor their achievements. The University has not yet made a decision regarding Commencement for the Class of 2021 and related end-of-year activities. Emails have been sent to the Class of 2020 and Class of 2021 as well as the alumni community with additional details.

column1: Twenty years ago::: #PrincetonU made history by becoming the first university in the country to remove loans from its financial aid packages. column1: Researchers from Princeton School of Public and International Affairs and University of Southern California have projected that::: due to #COVID19 deaths last year::: life expectancy at birth for Americans will shorten by more than one year. column1: Princeton University mourns the loss of Hank Aaron::: a 2011 honorary degree recipient::: who championed civil rights amidst a legendary baseball career. He held the title of "home run king" for decades::: had his number 44 retired in Milwaukee and Atlanta and earned a spot in the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum.  His Commencement bio reads::: "He was 17 when he left Alabama and embarked on one of the greatest careers in baseball history::: beginning in the Negro American League. When he joined the major league Milwaukee Braves::: his signing bonus was a cardboard suitcase. When he retired after 23 major league seasons::: he probably held the record for the most records held::: including the record for career home runs at 755. As he approached Babe Ruth’s record of 714::: he received almost a million letters::: many of them abusive. Today America is a much better place with much more opportunity for all::: in part because he gave all of us an imperishable example of grace under pressure."

"Our goal is to create a beloved community and this will require a qualitative change in our souls as well as a quantitative change in our lives." — Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.  For this year's Month of Service::: Pace Center for Civic Engagement::: Princeton University is encouraging all Princetonians to reflect on Dr. King's philosophy of a "Beloved Community." A Beloved Community::: in King’s understanding::: is a realistic achievable goal when people are committed to equity::: human decency::: inclusivity::: justice::: and conflict-resolution and reconciliation. Community is integral to the University in the service of humanity and even more so now as we weather a global pandemic::: reckonings around racial justice and equity::: and shifts in our political and societal landscapes ➡️ http://bit.ly/38CFsIu  In March of 1960::: Dr. King visited campus. Here he is seen walking down the steps of Chancellor Green alongside students and an assistant dean. column6: Good afternoon folks::: I completed the Professional Master's degree from PPGEB::: from UERJ in the city of Rio de Janeiro-Brazil. I researched educational games as facilitators for learning and teaching mathematics. I was blessed to do this work at E.M. Casimiro de Abreu::: where I work as a math teacher. I would like to give a special thanks to Principal Rose Annie::: to all colleagues::: parents::: guardians and students who with love and support helped to write a very beautiful page in my history as an educator. To this end::: we created two games on the theme: high school equations and their variations::: entitled: “Tá Dominado::: Tudo dominoes em Equações” and “Bingo no Pé::: what Equation is it?” That were applied in 9th grade classes. schooling and evaluated by students and teachers of Mathematics. The two educational games can be accessed at: Foot Bingo::: what Equation is it? https:// educapes.capes.g ov.br/handle/ capes/564405 Dominoes::: everything is dominated by Equations ... https:// educapes.capes.g ov.br/handle/ capes/564377 The publications above are educational products::: mandatory for the Professional Master's. The preparation of these materials is important for the democratization of knowledge and for the encouragement of academic practices and investigations. When accessing the links::: click on the file titles::: which are in blue. If you can::: download it::: so that it counts as “accessed”. Be sure to rate and comment on the products. If you can::: help me share this message! Thank you very much::: Vicente de Paula Soares Nunes.

column1: #TellUsTigers: “I first learned ‘The Swan’ by Camille Saint-Saëns when I was 11 years old. I remember watching a video of a Yo-Yo Ma performance and crying during the last iteration of the theme — it was that beautiful. I imagine the swan both passionate and poised as it glides along::: aware of its surroundings but unbothered by them. I have been trying to embody that mentality as I move through a world in which so much is beyond my control. When classes became virtual last spring::: I hoped to take advantage of my newly flexible schedule by practicing more. Instead::: I found myself struggling to prioritize cello. With no upcoming performances::: I didn’t have any goals. It felt ‘unproductive’ to play cello when I could be working on assignments::: sleeping or exercising. Part of me also dreaded the way I would sound when I picked up my cello again after a long time away. At the same time::: I did not feel like myself without playing cello. I realized that playing cello now is self-care — something I do on a regular basis just because it makes me feel better. My role as a student coach with @TrentonArtsatPrinceton has helped me stay on track with this ‘self-care journey.’ Every Saturday::: I have a Zoom with my Trenton Youth Orchestra student::: Brandon::: whom I started teaching a year ago. Brandon responds quickly to feedback and improves a lot during his lessons. Since the pandemic started::: however::: it has been challenging for him to find a time to practice that does not interrupt his family members’ work-related calls. One piece of advice I give him is that practicing for five minutes is better than not practicing at all. I tell him what he should focus on if he only has five minutes — sometimes it is just a single measure of music. I would give myself and everyone the same advice: an all-or-nothing mindset is never healthy and is especially unhealthy right now. If I can’t fit in cello practice::: I listen to music. One of my go-to pieces is Mozart’s Requiem. My family thinks I am dramatic for this::: but I think the enormity & timeless subject matter of the piece help me keep things in perspective.” — Katie Cappola ’23; video by David Kelly Crow #Princetagram

column4: Enjoyed reading this article on decision making during the pandemic. Found a significant contradiction in the article though. Eve Witttenberg::: a decision scientist at Harvard::: states 'people are not stupid here'. Really? Stupid is defined as having or showing a great lack of intelligence or common sense. I'll give people the benefit of the doubt and rule out the 'having' part of the definition because I don't want to accuse people unfairly of not having intelligence so I'll focus on the 'showing' part of the definition. If stupid can be defined by a great lack of showing intelligence::: how to you account for the behavior at the Sturgis motorcycle rally or at the Barrett nomination celebration? During the peak of a pandemic to not wear face coverings and to gather in close quarters either amongst the hundreds of thousands of bikers in South Dakota or the hundreds of political insiders at the Rose Garden depicts stupidity at its finest::: in my opinion.

column1: #TellUsTigersPartII x #WellnessWednesday: “During my senior year at Princeton::: I began having random nose bleeds and my medical provider informed me that I had high blood pressure and was on the brink of needing medication to regulate it. I was 22 years old and devastated by this news. It was the call to action I needed to prioritize my health and well-being. I was an active member of several campus organizations::: president of the Class of 2018 and a residential college adviser — on top of a rigorous academic course load and maintaining social connections. To cope with stress::: I turned to food. I knew that emotional eating negatively impacted my physical and mental health::: yet I felt helpless. I started many fad diets and exercise programs::: which led to further disappointment as I was not focused on creating long-term::: sustainable health goals. The first time I was featured in #TellUsTigers — on Dec. 21::: 2017 — I reflected on academic experiences where other students made assumptions about my identity solely based on my race::: and the importance of fostering inclusive educational environments. I didn’t touch on it then::: but I was also dealing with some personal health challenges. After graduation::: I started a fulltime job and introduced group fitness and mindful eating into my regular wellness practice. In the beginning::: I worked with a fitness coach to establish my goals and track my progress. I have accountability partners for support too. This year has presented unique challenges. The severity of the pandemic and working in a virtual environment introduced potential stressors for us all. As a Black man::: I have been affected by the disproportionate impact of COVID-19 on my community and acts of racial injustice happening globally. In a time of turbulence::: I have been able to find strength and stability through wellness and leaning on my supportive community. As there is not a one-size fits all approach to wellness::: everyone must endeavor on their own personal journey to discover what improves their well-being and makes them feel good.” — Brandon McGhee ’18; photo by Zhao Chen #Princetagram

column11: I work as an attorney::: and a good deal of my job involves human interaction and evaluation. AI can be used as a tool::: just as a hammer can be used as a tool. I can see how data and artificial intelligence can be useful::: but I don't believe AI can replace human intelligence (which is also flawed.)

column1: Scientists have discovered a rare object called the Blue Ring Nebula::: a ring of hydrogen gas with a star at its center. The properties of this system suggest it is the remnant of two stars meeting their ultimate demise: an inward orbital dance that resulted in the two stars merging. The result offers a new window into the fate of many tightly orbiting binary star systems.  PRINCETON.EDU In the mysterious Blue Ring Nebula::: scientists see the fate of binary stars

column89: Just have to respond to the trolling. Nuance is really important! And it should be fair to expect that the audience of this conversation is interested in nuance. The use of the terms "racism" and "white supremacy" in this context aren't meant to suggest that 60-70 million people in the country are racists insofar as they have individual animus toward black people. It's that they aren't interested in or attentive to the way that race exacerbates inequality in the United States::: and the fact that they don't really care about problems that are baked into our system.
column91: America is essentially still fighting our own Civil War. It didn't end in 1865 because Lincoln was too charitable to the Confederacy and the Union didn't properly mop up after the war. I don't say this flippantly. Reconstruction ended prematurely as an electoral compromise following a contested presidential election::: and we are even now paying the price.  Look at the election results: the Confederacy is very much alive and may even be winning. "Malice towards none" was a charitable moment::: but it was never reciprocated.

Two leaders of United We Dream::: the largest youth organization with more than 400:::000 members nationwide::: will discuss how the movement has evolved and the prospects for Congress to pass a Dream Act with a path to citizenship for undocumented youth. Princeton University::: Dreamer María Perales Sánchez '18 and Microsoft were among other plaintiffs who sued the federal government for terminating DACA in which the Supreme Court ruled to restore the DACA program: https://bit.ly/2zMENpiv  This event is not associated with any campaign. column1: "These results suggest that Princeton laboratory researchers are serious about safety." — Dean for Research Pablo Debenedetti  #PrincetonU is proud of our research community::: safely returning this summer to on-campus laboratory activities and reporting a high level of compliance with the University's health and safety protocols. 👏  PRINCETON.EDU Princeton researchers report high level of compliance with on-campus health and safety protocols

SNAI2 is a dangerous::: drug-resistant protein known as "the driver of cancer’s aggressiveness" that makes cancer cells invisible to the immune system and resistant to chemotherapy.  A team of Princeton researchers has found a way to "shred" and "recycle" this protein::: opening pathways to new kinds of cancer treatments.  PRINCETON.EDU Kang finds keys to control the ‘driver of cancer’s aggressiveness’
column3: Great Job 👌 Congratulations to the team 🏆

column1: Meet Maya Mishra ’22::: a #PrincetonU student well on her way to becoming one of the first people on Mars as a flight surgeon. During a high school summer internship at NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration::: Maya met NASA’s Chief Health and Medical Officer to learn more about his job. She gravitated toward his passion for aerospace medicine deciding immediately she did not belong behind a desk.  Shooting for the stars::: Maya is an ecology and evolutionary biology major at Princeton::: pursuing certificates in global health and health policy and planets and life. She also participates in Pace Center for Civic Engagement::: Princeton University's Service Focus program::: which combines service and academic work through internships::: a peer cohort::: faculty mentorship and coursework.  "Whatever path you choose::: there is a way to integrate service with it:::" says Maya. "Helping each other is just so human::: it’s biologically kind of coded into us."

column1: Princeton mourns the loss of Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg::: a 2010 honorary degree recipient::: who dedicated her life to fighting for gender equality and championing women's rights.  The following was read aloud when she received her honorary Doctor of Laws degree at Princetons’ 263rd Commencement: "Denied deserved recognition by a discriminatory profession when she graduated at the top of her law school class::: she has dedicated her life to vindicating the Constitution’s promise of equality under law as a distinguished law professor::: a respected Supreme Court litigator and a trailblazing advocate for women’s rights. Through brilliant strategy and rigorous argument::: she persuaded the Supreme Court to recognize a constitutional right to be free from sex discrimination. Her triumphs earned her a seat on the bench and eventually on this nation’s highest court::: where her jurisprudence is a beacon of freedom that illuminates the continuing power of America’s constitutional ideals.”  Photo by The Star-Ledger.

column1: “We see this gift as the color of commitment. It celebrates the many contributions to Princeton’s legacy from its diverse students and alumni making a tremendous impact in the world. It represents what it means for us to individually and collectively thrive. It demonstrates that people of color belong in the room and sit at the table as patrons and co-creators to help the University to continue to do the work of service to humanity. Most importantly::: during this time of national reckoning on race and racial injustice::: it highlights the benefits that diversity::: inclusion and belonging can bring. Princeton is a microcosm of America; we’re modeling that working together makes us all stronger moving forward”  Princeton alumni Kwanza Jones ‘93 and José E. Feliciano ‘94 have made a major gift to the University - the largest ever made by Black and Latino donors and one of a few extraordinary alumni commitments to the University's strategic goal of undergraduate expansion - leading to the construction of two new undergraduate dormitories. The dormitory buildings will be named after Jones and Feliciano::: becoming the first two buildings on campus named for Black and Latino benefactors. https://bit.ly/3hCZt2H  #PrincetonForward

An excerpt:  "I remember horse and carriages on Nassau Street::: and the trolley that went from Witherspoon Street to Trenton::: where the stores were. The schools in Princeton were segregated [until 1948]; they had one school on Quarry Street for the blacks and the whites had two schools other than Catholic and private schools.  "Before I came to work at Princeton::: I worked at Princeton Hospital for 18 years. The hospital was segregated::: the blacks had one section::: the whites had another section. We had one black doctor::: he lived right around the corner from me. He could put you in the hospital but he could not come see you because all the doctors and nurses were white."

“This is a monumental opportunity for Princeton to contribute to the fast-evolving technological future of quantum computing.”  Princeton University will have a major leadership role in a new Co-Design Center for Quantum Advantage (C2QA)::: headquartered at Brookhaven National Laboratory and funded by the U.S. Department of Energy. Join us for the latest webinar in Princeton University Library's Special Collections Highlights Series to celebrate the centenary of the 19th amendment on Women’s Equality Day. On Aug. 26::: 1920::: the 19th amendment was signed and sealed by Secretary of State Bainbridge Colby::: prohibiting both states and the federal government from denying the right to vote on the basis of sex. Lauren Santangelo::: lecturer in Princeton Writing Program and author of "Suffrage and the City: New York Women Battle for the Ballot:::" will talk about her book::: along with Sara Howard::: librarian for gender and sexuality studies and student engagement::: and Julie Mellby::: graphic arts curator.  As one critic wrote::: "'Suffrage and the City' is one more jewel in the crown of informative writing on the suffrage movement. Santangelo offers fresh and interesting perspectives in her focus on urban spaces::: covering oft-tread ground with a bright new analysis. Her book sets a high standard for future scholars who focus on women’s rights::: organizations::: and activism::: and it reminds us how fascinating the topics remain.”  Throughout the conversation the speakers will be playing the 1908 suffragette board game Pank-A-Squith! Printed as a fundraiser for the Women’s Social and Political Union in Britain::: Pank-a-Squith was named after the suffragette leader Emmeline Pankhurst and Herbert Asquith::: British Prime Minister from 1908 to 1916 and a strong opponent of women’s suffrage. While the game is British::: the focus of our talk will be the American anniversary and resources available in the Princeton University Library.

column1: #TellUsTigers: "The most important lesson I’ve learned at Princeton University is to be myself. I used to be so focused on what the ‘ideal’ Princeton student was::: I almost didn’t apply. In high school::: my parents divorced. Within two weeks::: my mother::: brother and I completely restarted our lives. When college application season came around::: I was so drained from the accumulated trauma that I did not want to risk rejection from my dream school. So::: I had initially given up on the Ivy League. One night::: my cousin Christian came over for dinner and spoke about the importance of taking the opportunity::: convincing me to apply to Princeton. A few months later things fell into place::: and I became a member of Princeton’s Class of 2021. Once at #PrincetonU::: I found myself so focused on ‘fitting in.’ At the time::: I struggled to articulate exactly who I wanted to be — but I knew I wanted to fit in somewhere. In waiting for others to see me::: I felt invisible. It can be difficult to exist at Princeton as your authentic self for many reasons. I perceived elite perfection to be most valued. For me::: internalized white supremacy and imposter syndrome had me believing that I did not deserve to walk the halls my ancestors helped build. As I started to gain more confidence::: I created spaces such as Black Pre-Med Society and Black Organization for Leadership Development (BOLD)::: a mentorship program for underserved high school students::: in the hopes that other people can be empowered to be authentically themselves. I stopped asking for a seat at the table and built my own::: welcoming others in. I decided to pursue medical anthropology as my major because it interrogates health in a sick society that allows for a select few to eat at the table::: while the majority starve. Through intentional study and practice in public health::: we can create the reality for a more just future. As a rising senior::: I learned to define myself for myself. I am so grateful for my mother::: family::: friends::: mentors::: and boyfriend who continue to encourage and empower me to keep walking in my own truth::: charting my own path." — Angelika Nattiel Morris ’21; photo by Zhamoyani McMillan '21 #Princetagram
column3: Way to go::: Angelika! So happy you’ve found your stride and I appreciate and identify with your perspective. My experience was different::: of course::: back in the late 90’s but something here definitely resonates. Thank you for sharing your truth.

column1: #TellUsTigers: “When #COVID19 hit and colleges across the country had to send students home::: I had to worry about securing housing for the first time in my life. Princeton is 9:::314 miles away from Malaysia and I had less than a week to decide if returning to my family was even possible. I will never forget that week that I spent discussing with other international students about what in the world we were all going to do. Travel bans were being put in place::: flight prices were soaring and we were all worried about our visa status. To have my notion of home taken away from me prematurely was scary and destabilizing. As an international student::: Princeton had been my one and only home in the United States. I had no family here::: and I had no home to return to in this country. As I considered what to do::: I remembered the first night of freshman orientation when I saw the beautiful stained glass windows of Richardson Auditorium — that was when it dawned on me that Princeton would be my new home. Home has always had a unique meaning to me because I have lived away from ‘home’ for half my life. I went to two boarding schools in Malaysia on scholarship between the ages of 13 to 20 before I came to Princeton. As I fell in love with the campus and my college experience as a #firstgen::: low-income student::: Princeton began to feel like home more and more. After the University sent students home in March::: I called many different places my temporary home. For the remainder of the semester::: I was able to stay in my room in Spelman after all my roommates had left. The house on Bank Street where I moved off campus to with a few friends. My friend’s home in California where she and her family graciously let me stay. The tent that we camped in at seven national parks to make up for our lost post-graduation trip. Despite all of the changes happening in the world now::: there is one thing that has remained constant: the friends I have made at Princeton University over the last four years. In times like these::: I am reminded that it is the people::: not the places::: in my life that I can call home.” — Ben Yap '20; photo by David Kelly Crow #Princetagram #Princeton2020 #FLI

column1: #TellUsTigers: “I am a Class of 2020 Princeton University graduate but first and foremost I graduated as a FLI (first-generation/low-income) student. I am #FLI::: but I'm not the first in my family to attend a university because my older sister Melissa attended UC San Diego. Academically::: I followed in her footsteps in a lot of ways. At Orange Glen High School in Escondido::: California::: she led me right into the care of one of our teachers::: Ms. Rachel Bronwyn::: a 1991 Princeton alumna with a master's in art history from Williams College. Her mission? Share her love of art history and literature with under-resourced students in City of Escondido. She is known for being an eclectic teacher who works intensely to support others. ‘I think you should start looking at schools like this’ were the first words Ms. Bronwyn said to me::: blinking twice emphatically (the Bronwyn Blink) after barging into one of my high school classes freshman year and shoving a pamphlet for Williams College into my hands. Ms. Bronwyn became a second mother to me. She was the one who told me about QuestBridge::: which matches high-achieving students from low-income backgrounds with leading colleges and universities. She taught me how to aim high. She barged into another of my classes on December 1::: 2015::: almost exactly four years after the first time. This time she was sobbing with joy after I had opened my Princeton acceptance email. I had been matched through Questbridge — the happiest day of my life. She shoved an oversized orange tee shirt into my hands before excusing herself to make a sign that would cover a wall of the high school administration building for weeks saying ‘Princeton said yes to our Tabitha!’ Ms. Bronwyn had not returned to #PrincetonU for more than 20 years and the odds of her making the trip decreased after being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis during my senior year of high school. You can imagine my surprise when I checked my phone during the She Roars alumni conference weekend and read: ‘I am in a tent on Poe Field. You weren't expecting that text::: were you?’” — Tabitha Belshee ’20 #Princetagram #Princeton20

column1: #TellUsTigers: “Growing up in Sri Lanka::: I initially never considered pursuing higher education in the United States. Most colleges do not offer low-income international students financial aid. Of the few that do::: only a handful of highly selective universities are need-blind. I had another inherent disadvantage: Could the English I learned by reading children’s adventure stories by candlelight — power cuts are common where I grew up — match up to that of a native speaker? I found Princeton through a Google search for colleges that would offer me aid. After being accepted::: I assumed the struggle was over. I spent my first days on campus marveling — no more mosquito nets or jittery Wi-Fi! My illusions were rudely shattered hours before day one of classes. I trudged back to the bookstore to return all the textbooks I had purchased the previous night::: guilty at having spent the equivalent of a month’s salary in Sri Lanka. After that::: I would usually pick classes that my friends also chose so I could share their textbooks. Enduring winter break in solitude on campus was cheaper than buying a ticket home. Two jobs at a library and as a teaching assistant took up 8 precious hours each week. Through it all::: I was fortunate to befriend and room with several other international students in similar situations. We shared our reasons for coming to the US::: bemoaned the fact that our financial aid was taxed and made fun of the imperial system of measurement. Although arduous at times::: my experience at Princeton contributed to my intellectual and personal development in a manner that would never have been possible had I not chosen to leave my home country for college. I had studied a strictly linear curriculum in Sri Lanka::: so the academic diversity of the liberal arts system was a refreshing change. From working with bees in England to cataloging ancient coins at Firestone Library::: my summers were never boring. Wrapping up senior year in Spelman Hall::: overlooking the courtyard with the Picasso statue::: where it all began at International Orientation::: I am certain that my Princeton University journey was worthwhile.” — Sandun Bambarandage ’20; photo by David Kelly Crow #Princetagram

column1: While the Princeton Pianists Ensemble was set to perform in person this spring::: they didn’t let separation stop them from performing their brand new piece::: “Disney Fantasy Medley:::" co-arranged by Audrey Shih ’20. 🎹  What’s your favorite song featured in the piece? Let us know in the comments below.  Princeton Pianists Ensemble May 20::: 2020 at 2:32 PM ·  The Princeton Pianists Ensemble presents a Disney Fantasy Medley — the world’s first remotely performed piece for 5 pianos. Arranged by Audrey Shih (Princeton '20) and Avery Farm (NYU '21)::: this medley of favorite pieces from Disney movies was originally to be performed live at the Princeton Pianists Ensemble’s spring 2020 concert. Due to the COVID-19 crisis::: the performers recorded their parts separately in quarantine. Performed by Albert H. W. Jiang '21::: Andre Yin '22::: Audrey Shih '20::: Jacqueline Xu '22::: and Phillip Yoon '20. Audio engineered by Albert H. W. Jiang and video edited by Jacqueline Xu.  As pioneers in the art of collaborative piano::: the Princeton Pianists Ensemble (PPE) challenges the notion that piano is only a solo instrument and push the traditional boundaries of how the instrument is performed. Four hands on one piano::: ten hands on five pianos::: and everything in between — we’ve done it or we’ll do it. Our mission is nothing less than to make beautiful music accessible to all and to spread it around Princeton and the world.  Don't forget::: PPE is essential during a pandemic! For more of our music::: check out our YouTube channel at https://www.youtube.com/user/PrincetonPianists and our website at www.princetonpianists.com.

column1: #TellUsTigers: “I was born in the Philippines and moved to the US with my family in 2006. My junior year of high school::: I was admitted to LEDA Leadership Enterprise for a Diverse America::: a summer program hosted at Princeton to help high-achieving students from under-resourced backgrounds gain admission to college. During my time at LEDA::: I fell in love with Princeton’s campus::: decided to apply and was admitted. My acceptance was so surprising and exciting — I would be the first to attend college in my family. My 4 years at Princeton opened so many opportunities. I traveled the world::: to Thailand as a Streicker Fellow::: to the Philippines for Princeton School of Public and International Affairs senior thesis research and to India with my South Asian studies class ‘Gender::: Sexuality and Feminism in South Asia.’ I met lifelong friends throughout the years and am thankful for the Freshman Scholars Institute and Scholars Institute Fellows Program for providing me a community of friends and mentors my first year at Princeton. Looking back as a #FLI student::: navigating Princeton can be challenging and lonely::: but the support from faculty and alumni mentors and especially my friends helped get me through the most difficult times. Graduating virtually was bittersweet and even more so for my family since this college graduation would have been the first for us::: and my brother Dan will be entering as a member of Class of 2024. My heart goes out to my fellow classmates who identify as FLI like me. Commencement represents a celebration of sacrifice and overcoming of challenges — I celebrate with you on graduating #PrincetonU. With my senior year ending so abruptly::: I urge the Class of 2024 to treasure your moments in the next four years::: explore your interests::: try new things and ask for help when you need it. I am very grateful for the Class of 2020 for providing me with so many memories to treasure. While we graduated together virtually::: I’m looking forward to next year when we gather to celebrate on campus. Until then::: a huge congratulations to the Great Class of 2020::: I’m so excited for what the future holds!” — Jona Mojados ’20 with her brother Eudan Mojados::: writing from Upper Chichester::: PA

column1: Princeton stands firmly with our international students.  On July 6::: United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) announced a precipitous::: unexpected change in policy affecting international students at Princeton and throughout the country.  The announced changes are heartless::: senseless::: and damaging: they needlessly put international students at risk without serving any legitimate policy objective.  Princeton is filing an amicus brief in the lawsuit that Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) brought against Department of Homeland Security and Immigration And Customs Enforcement (ICE) earlier today.  The University is also exploring other legal and policy options::: as well as other University actions that might solve the problems created by ICE’s announcement.  Read more in a letter from President Eisgruber to the campus community.https://bit.ly/2WfRcdx  PRINCETON.EDU President Eisgruber: Princeton stands firmly with international students in face of ICE announcement

Undergraduates may return to campus for one semester during the 2020-21 academic year::: with first-year students and juniors welcomed to campus for the fall semester::: and sophomores and seniors welcomed for the spring semester; all graduate students who wish to may stay in campus graduate housing for the upcoming academic year.
