column29: As an African American alum of both the school the university and even the residential college for all four years I was deeply disappointed to learn Wilson’s racist history AFTER I graduated. That is something I wish the university had shared.  As the the only African American male in my class at the now Princeton School of Public and International affairs::: the programs and school felt cold as if it was just a place I was visiting and not the home of my major. This was despite some welcoming faculty who aided me in my future career in policy and government.  Upon learning the history later it was obvious to me that Wilson having his way would’ve meant I never attended the university::: that my parents never worked for the Federal Government and that I never would’ve worked in the house in which he once lived::: as a policy advisor.  I’m glad he didn’t get his way ::: well forever::: but I lament all of those black men and women who came before me who because of him never had the chance to attend the university or work for Uncle Sam::: and who’s families suffered economic inequalities as a result.  The name should’ve been changed in 2016 as I shared with Trustees then::: but I’m proud of my alma mater for making this change now. Even prouder finally to be an alum of the school and university.  You are like America::: finally beginning to hear us.

column1: Princeton University's Board of Trustees has voted to remove Woodrow Wilson’s name from the School of Public Policy and International Affairs and residential college. The trustees have concluded that Wilson’s racist thinking and policies make him an inappropriate namesake for a school or college whose scholars and alumni must stand firmly against racism in all its forms. The public policy school will now be known as Princeton School of Public and International Affairs and the residential college will be known as "First College." These are not the only steps our University is taking to combat the realities and legacy of racism::: but they are important ones.  PRINCETON.EDU President Eisgruber's message to community on removal of Woodrow Wilson name from public policy school and Wilson College

column5: Histories of Princeton University have since celebrated the school as a contribution to a growing democratic spirit in the colonies—a sentiment that eventually led to the American Revolutionary War. What those histories fail to mention::: however::: is that every single one of the seven founding trustees was a slaveholder. What’s more::: of the five trustees added to the charter in 1747::: four were slaveholders::: bringing the total to eleven out of twelve. By the time a second charter was granted in 1748::: thirteen additional trustees had been added::: making for twenty-three trustees in total (two of those included in 1747 did not sign the 1748 charter).[4] Of the thirteen trustees added in 1748::: seven were slaveholders.

Those needs have become more visible with the black lives lost to COVID-19::: police violence::: and citizen vigilantism. Persistent::: recent::: and continuing acts of systemic racism are calling us all in the University community to address inequalities and injustices. In response::: the Pace Center is launching Princeton RISE (Recognizing Inequalities and Standing for Equality)::: a new grant initiative.  Now through June 22::: all matriculated Princeton University undergraduate and graduate students can apply to receive a $1:::500 grant to listen to and work with communities; explore and advocate for racial justice broadly; learn about societal inequities in areas such as health::: criminal justice::: and education; and make a substantive contribution to the research and mission of campus and community partners.

column1: Join us to listen to the premiere episode of "We Roar" featuring Dr. Céline Gounder from the Great Class of 1997::: an attending physician at New York's Bellevue Hospital::: serving on the frontline of the coronavirus pandemic. She has a specialty in infectious disease and a second career as a medical journalist. Afterward::: Dr. Gounder will answer viewer questions. Please leave your questions in the comments for the chance to be answered on-air.  We Roar Listening Party and Q&A with Dr. Céline Gounder '97
column3: Could Dr. Gounder explain the utility of monitoring body temperature before allowing someone to enter a store::: school or airplane? How has temperature monitoring been used in other epidemics? Is there evidence that temperature monitoring arrests spread (in other epidemics as well as the current one)?
column4: Please ask Dr. Gounder to speak about antibody testing - should people take a test now or wait until a more reliable test is available or wait until more is known about COVID-19 antibodies overall?
column5: While universities are deciding whether or not to bring students back to campus::: isn’t it true that we have no real data on what this would mean re COVID spread since at the beginning of the outbreak most college aged students as well as k-12 were home and in quarantine. Won’t bringing students back from all locations to one campus for the first time be a perfect way to redistribute the geographical spread and siphon it to places confined to congregate living and the surrounding communities::: and then once again as the students go back home?
column6: Leave questions in comments here::: or during the episode?

column1: As COVID-19 has swept across the United States::: it has unmasked and amplified existing racial inequities. Rampant fear and misinformation has provoked a wave of discrimination::: harassment::: and hate targeting those of Chinese and Asian descent. The disease has also had a disproportionate toll on historically marginalized populations::: including African Americans and Native Americans::: due to unequal access to health care::: residential segregation::: poverty::: and incarceration. Join a conversation that will situate these developments within the long history of racism::: exclusion::: and scapegoating in the United States. Panelists will discuss strategies to address marginalization and empower impacted communities.  Panelists:  Andy Kim::: Congressman from New Jersey’s 3rd District Beth Lew-Williams::: Associate Professor of History::: Princeton University Keith Wailoo::: Chair and Henry Putnam University Professor of History and Public Affairs Helen Zia ’73::: Activist and author Aly Kassam-Remtulla::: Associate Provost for International Affairs::: Princeton University (moderator)  Sponsored by the Associate Provost for International Affairs and Operations and the Vice Provost for Institutional Equity and Diversity  Race in the COVID Era: What America’s History of Racism and Xenophobia Means for Today
